      Learn About 9-1-1 Tips
    • Monthly Calls to 9-1-1
      233,507
      in June 2023
    • 9-1-1
      Education Materials

    • Calling 9-1-1

      9-1-1 is for police, fire, or medical emergencies when immediate action is required: someone’s health, safety or property is in jeopardy or a crime is in progress.

      Learn More

    • Non-Emergency Calls

      Don’t let non-emergencies compete with real ones. Know the difference between when to call 9-1-1 and when to report your situation to the non-emergency line.

      Learn More

    • Public Safety Technology

      ​E-Comm offers public safety technology and dispatch services that allow police, fire and ambulance agencies to communicate across municipal boundaries.

      Learn More

    Join Our Team

    ​Be part of the team helping to save lives and protect property in British Columbia.

    Learn More

    @EComm911_info
    Mistakes happen. If you call 9-1-1 by accident, don’t hang up – please stay on the line and let us know you’re safe.

    #DYK: you can disable the emergency SOS feature on many cellphones to help prevent accidental 9-1-1 calls. #911BC #HelpUsHelp https://t.co/8tIX7kZr1y

    E-Comm 9115 hours ago
    Are you looking for meaningful work? Get the inside scoop on a 9-1-1 call-taking career with E-Comm in our next virtual info session happening on July 20, 5:30 p.m. – 6:30 p.m. PST.: https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/6916836549680/WN_3L5ykcMUQX-Try9_t23RbA#/registration

    2    View on Facebook
    E-Comm 9112 days ago
    Did you know that many smartphones have an Emergency SOS feature that dials 9-1-1 when the side buttons are repeatedly pressed? While this may be helpful in certain scenarios, this is a big culprit for accidental 9-1-1 calls!

    Mistakes happen. If you call 9-1-1 by accident, don’t hang up. Please stay on the line and let us know you’re safe. Our call takers treat every call as an emergency until they can deem otherwise.

    #HelpUsHelp prevent accidental calls by locking and storing your phones safely. #911BC
    E-Comm 9115 days ago
    “I am excited to help lead the Non-Emergency Call-Taking team because it is a new venture for E-Comm to live up to our mission to save lives and to protect property,” shares Anthony, one of our non-emergency call taker team leads. He’s excited for the new dedicated non-emergency call-taking team to serve British Columbians.

    Do you know when to call 9-1-1 vs. the police non-emergency line? Anthony recommends visiting nonemergency.ca before making a non-emergency call to see if your non-urgent police matter can be reported online or diverted to a more appropriate resources.

    Don’t forget: always call 9-1-1 when your health, safety or property is in danger or a crime is in progress and you require immediate assistance from police, fire or ambulance.

    #911BC #NonEmergTips #911Tips
       View on Facebook
    E-Comm 9111 week ago
    Text with 9-1-1 is a specialized service available to the Deaf, Deafened, Hard of Hearing or Speech Impaired (DHHSI) community in B.C. To utilize this service, you must register with your wireless service provider and have a compatible cellphone. Visit textwith911.ca to learn how #TextWith911 works, where the service is available, and to register. #911BC
       View on Facebook
    E-Comm 9112 weeks ago
    Thank you to all E-Comm employees and first responders working over the long weekend and throughout the year to make #BC a safer place to live. We are grateful for your contributions to public safety. #911BC

        “I am excited to help lead the Non-Emergency Call-Taking team because it is a new venture for E-Comm to live up to our mission to save lives and to protect property,” shares Anthony, one of our non-emergency call taker team leads. He’s excited for the new dedicated non-emergency call-taking team to serve British Columbians.

        Do you know when to call 9-1-1 vs. the police non-emergency line? Anthony recommends visiting nonemergency.ca before making a non-emergency call to see if your non-urgent police matter can be reported online or diverted to a more appropriate resources.

        Don’t forget: always call 9-1-1 when your health, safety or property is in danger or a crime is in progress and you require immediate assistance from police, fire or ambulance.

        #911BC #NonEmergTips #911Tips
           View on Facebook
        E-Comm 9111 week ago
        Text with 9-1-1 is a specialized service available to the Deaf, Deafened, Hard of Hearing or Speech Impaired (DHHSI) community in B.C. To utilize this service, you must register with your wireless service provider and have a compatible cellphone. Visit textwith911.ca to learn how #TextWith911 works, where the service is available, and to register. #911BC
           View on Facebook
        E-Comm 9112 weeks ago
        Thank you to all E-Comm employees and first responders working over the long weekend and throughout the year to make #BC a safer place to live. We are grateful for your contributions to public safety. #911BC

                      E-Comm 9112 days ago
                      Did you know that many smartphones have an Emergency SOS feature that dials 9-1-1 when the side buttons are repeatedly pressed? While this may be helpful in certain scenarios, this is a big culprit for accidental 9-1-1 calls!

                      Mistakes happen. If you call 9-1-1 by accident, don’t hang up. Please stay on the line and let us know you’re safe. Our call takers treat every call as an emergency until they can deem otherwise.

                      #HelpUsHelp prevent accidental calls by locking and storing your phones safely. #911BC
                      E-Comm 9115 days ago
                      “I am excited to help lead the Non-Emergency Call-Taking team because it is a new venture for E-Comm to live up to our mission to save lives and to protect property,” shares Anthony, one of our non-emergency call taker team leads. He’s excited for the new dedicated non-emergency call-taking team to serve British Columbians.

                      Do you know when to call 9-1-1 vs. the police non-emergency line? Anthony recommends visiting nonemergency.ca before making a non-emergency call to see if your non-urgent police matter can be reported online or diverted to a more appropriate resources.

                      Don’t forget: always call 9-1-1 when your health, safety or property is in danger or a crime is in progress and you require immediate assistance from police, fire or ambulance.

                      #911BC #NonEmergTips #911Tips
                         View on Facebook
                      E-Comm 9111 week ago
                      Text with 9-1-1 is a specialized service available to the Deaf, Deafened, Hard of Hearing or Speech Impaired (DHHSI) community in B.C. To utilize this service, you must register with your wireless service provider and have a compatible cellphone. Visit textwith911.ca to learn how #TextWith911 works, where the service is available, and to register. #911BC

                          Helping to Save Lives and Protect Property

                        • E-Comm 9-1-1

                          Helping to Save Lives and Protect Property

                        • Help Us Help
                          Learn About 9-1-1 Tips
                        • Monthly Calls to 9-1-1
                          233,507
                          in June 2023
                        • 9-1-1
                          Education Materials

                        • Calling 9-1-1

                          9-1-1 is for police, fire, or medical emergencies when immediate action is required: someone’s health, safety or property is in jeopardy or a crime is in progress.

                          Learn More

                        • Non-Emergency Calls

                          Don’t let non-emergencies compete with real ones. Know the difference between when to call 9-1-1 and when to report your situation to the non-emergency line.

                          Learn More

                        • Public Safety Technology

                          ​E-Comm offers public safety technology and dispatch services that allow police, fire and ambulance agencies to communicate across municipal boundaries.

                          Learn More

                        Join Our Team

                        ​Be part of the team helping to save lives and protect property in British Columbia.

                        Learn More

                        2    View on Facebook
                        E-Comm 9112 days ago
                        Did you know that many smartphones have an Emergency SOS feature that dials 9-1-1 when the side buttons are repeatedly pressed? While this may be helpful in certain scenarios, this is a big culprit for accidental 9-1-1 calls!

                        Mistakes happen. If you call 9-1-1 by accident, don’t hang up. Please stay on the line and let us know you’re safe. Our call takers treat every call as an emergency until they can deem otherwise.

                        #HelpUsHelp prevent accidental calls by locking and storing your phones safely. #911BC
                        E-Comm 9115 days ago
                        “I am excited to help lead the Non-Emergency Call-Taking team because it is a new venture for E-Comm to live up to our mission to save lives and to protect property,” shares Anthony, one of our non-emergency call taker team leads. He’s excited for the new dedicated non-emergency call-taking team to serve British Columbians.

                        Do you know when to call 9-1-1 vs. the police non-emergency line? Anthony recommends visiting nonemergency.ca before making a non-emergency call to see if your non-urgent police matter can be reported online or diverted to a more appropriate resources.

                        Don’t forget: always call 9-1-1 when your health, safety or property is in danger or a crime is in progress and you require immediate assistance from police, fire or ambulance.

                        #911BC #NonEmergTips #911Tips
                           View on Facebook
                        E-Comm 9111 week ago
                        Text with 9-1-1 is a specialized service available to the Deaf, Deafened, Hard of Hearing or Speech Impaired (DHHSI) community in B.C. To utilize this service, you must register with your wireless service provider and have a compatible cellphone. Visit textwith911.ca to learn how #TextWith911 works, where the service is available, and to register. #911BC
                           View on Facebook
                        E-Comm 9112 weeks ago
                        Thank you to all E-Comm employees and first responders working over the long weekend and throughout the year to make #BC a safer place to live. We are grateful for your contributions to public safety. #911BC

                            E-Comm 9112 days ago
                            Did you know that many smartphones have an Emergency SOS feature that dials 9-1-1 when the side buttons are repeatedly pressed? While this may be helpful in certain scenarios, this is a big culprit for accidental 9-1-1 calls!

                            Mistakes happen. If you call 9-1-1 by accident, don’t hang up. Please stay on the line and let us know you’re safe. Our call takers treat every call as an emergency until they can deem otherwise.

                            #HelpUsHelp prevent accidental calls by locking and storing your phones safely. #911BC
                            E-Comm 9115 days ago
                            “I am excited to help lead the Non-Emergency Call-Taking team because it is a new venture for E-Comm to live up to our mission to save lives and to protect property,” shares Anthony, one of our non-emergency call taker team leads. He’s excited for the new dedicated non-emergency call-taking team to serve British Columbians.

                            Do you know when to call 9-1-1 vs. the police non-emergency line? Anthony recommends visiting nonemergency.ca before making a non-emergency call to see if your non-urgent police matter can be reported online or diverted to a more appropriate resources.

                            Don’t forget: always call 9-1-1 when your health, safety or property is in danger or a crime is in progress and you require immediate assistance from police, fire or ambulance.

                            #911BC #NonEmergTips #911Tips

                            E-Comm 9111 week ago
                            Text with 9-1-1 is a specialized service available to the Deaf, Deafened, Hard of Hearing or Speech Impaired (DHHSI) community in B.C. To utilize this service, you must register with your wireless service provider and have a compatible cellphone. Visit textwith911.ca to learn how #TextWith911 works, where the service is available, and to register. #911BC
